item.title: Ticket #5015 (Add_Filter priority fails with some hooks) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: Ah, that's because wpautop() (which turns line breaks into paragraphs) is a filter on the_content with a priority of 10. So before that (1-9), you're dealing with line breaks. After that (11 and up), you'll have paragraph tags.

item.title: Ticket #5050 (the_category and get_the_category_list should accept post ID as an argument) created
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description:
There are a number of times when it would be nice to get the categories for a post outside of the loop.

My patch allows one to specify the post id, with no back-compat issues, as get_the_category_list calls get_the_category, which already can accept post ID as an argument.

item.title: Ticket #5048 (Update jQuery form plugin) created
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description:
The script-loader registers the jQuery form plugin with the wrong version. This might create a problem if someone checks against the plugin version, as it's an old version.

Speaking of which, could we please, please include the newest version of the jQuery form plugin, which I've attached, in 2.3? Although the script-loader registers the form plugin, trunk WP does not enqueue it anywhere yet, so updating to the newest version of the form plugin should have no effect on core WP.

item.title: Ticket #5015 (Add_Filter priority fails with some hooks) updated
item.dc:creator: mattyrob
item.description:
You are quite right - no bug in the add_filter code. Still something funny going on though.

Basically I've fixed my issue so I'll leave this ticket closed but..

I have a preg_replace looking for (<p>)(\n)*<!--subscribe2-->(\n)*(</p>) which worked fine with no priority set and with the priority set as 10. Lower than this it fails unless I change my regualr expression to <!--subscribe2-->.

item.title: Ticket #5047 (dbDelta generates E_WARNING if no indices are defined) updated
item.dc:creator: arnee
item.description: Keywords, Status changed

item.title: dbDelta.diff attached to Ticket #5047
item.dc:creator: arnee
item.description: if(is_array($indices)) Diff

item.title: Ticket #5047 (dbDelta generates E_WARNING if no indices are defined) created
item.dc:creator: arnee
item.description:
dbDelta tries to loop through the array of indexes with foreach, but this array is NULL if no indexes are defined. Foreach with NULL => E_WARNING

Solution: Check if $indices is an array

item.title: Ticket #4981 (the_tags functions : add a param for no tags) updated
item.dc:creator: momo360modena
item.description: Severity changed

item.title: Ticket #5046 (Statistics API for the Plugin Directory) created
item.dc:creator: johnbillion
item.description:
Are there any plans for an API for plugin download statistics on the ​Plugin Directory?

Wouldn't it be great to be able to display the total number of downloads for your plugin on your blog, just like on your plugin's statistics page on wordpress.org/extend.

A simple XML file is all that would be needed. I see there's already an XML file[1] for recent download activity (which is used to build the graph on the stats page) but none for total downloads etc.

How about it?

[1] Example: ​http://wordpress.org/extend/stats/plugin-xml.php?slug=podpress

item.title: Ticket #5044 (WordPress database error) created
item.dc:creator: mann3r
item.description:
when moderating comment, it always go to this WordPress database error: [Table 'mydatabase.wp_post2cat' doesn't exist] SELECT cat_ID AS ID, MAX(post_modified) AS last_mod FROM wp_posts p LEFT JOIN wp_post2cat pc ON p.ID = pc.post_id LEFT JOIN wp_categories c ON pc.category_id = c.cat_ID WHERE post_status = 'publish' GROUP BY cat_ID

WordPress database error: [Table 'mydatabase.wp_post2cat' doesn't exist] SELECT cat_ID AS ID, MAX(post_modified) AS last_mod FROM wp_posts p LEFT JOIN wp_post2cat pc ON p.ID = pc.post_id LEFT JOIN wp_categories c ON pc.category_id = c.cat_ID WHERE post_status = 'publish' GROUP BY cat_ID

WordPress database error: [Table 'mydatabase.wp_post2cat' doesn't exist] SELECT cat_ID AS ID, MAX(post_modified) AS last_mod FROM wp_posts p LEFT JOIN wp_post2cat pc ON p.ID = pc.post_id LEFT JOIN wp_categories c ON pc.category_id = c.cat_ID WHERE post_status = 'publish' GROUP BY cat_ID

WordPress database error: [Table 'mydatabase.wp_post2cat' doesn't exist] SELECT cat_ID AS ID, MAX(post_modified) AS last_mod FROM wp_posts p LEFT JOIN wp_post2cat pc ON p.ID = pc.post_id LEFT JOIN wp_categories c ON pc.category_id = c.cat_ID WHERE post_status = 'publish' GROUP BY cat_ID

WordPress database error: [Table 'mydatabase.wp_post2cat' doesn't exist] SELECT cat_ID AS ID, MAX(post_modified) AS last_mod FROM wp_posts p LEFT JOIN wp_post2cat pc ON p.ID = pc.post_id LEFT JOIN wp_categories c ON pc.category_id = c.cat_ID WHERE post_status = 'publish' GROUP BY cat_ID

but trying to refresh the browser yield to a success with no error.

item.title: Ticket #5033 (Better error_reporting and a debug mode) updated
item.dc:creator: darkdragon
item.description:
It is not my intention to be rude, the code would functionality be the same as it is now but allow those who want to see all errors to see them. However, I think that it should be instead assumed that if there is no WPDEBUG constant in wp-config.php, that the server is production.

In this way, I don't have to keep replacing the E_ALL with "0" each time I upgrade.

item.title: Ticket #5034 (Impossible to have duplicate category slugs with different parents) updated
item.dc:creator: snakefoot
item.description:
Guess one should be able to change the inner workings of the API, so terms are identified using the taxonomy-id instead. Post-categories, link-categories and tags would use taxonomy-id as their id.

This wouldn't break API's (one can always get a unique term using the taxonomy-id). Though it would change id's for all taxonomy-types (like ids changes with WP 2.3), and plugins will require a new API to aquire the actual term-id.

But it will pretty much require a complete rewrite of all taxonomy code :)

Guess I'm stuck with WP 2.0

item.title: Ticket #5034 (Impossible to have duplicate category slugs with different parents) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: In retrospect, we probably should have gone with passing term_taxonomy_id instead of term_id + taxonomy around the API and adding parent to the term_taxonomy keying. But, term_id + taxonomy is what we have. I think we'll have to make new term_ids with unique slugs to work around this.

item.title: Changeset [6151]: Core and plugin update checking: make sure fsockopen() is available ...
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: Core and plugin update checking: make sure fsockopen() is available and check file resources with is_resource() -- both to prevent feof() infinite loops. Props xknown. fixes #5037

item.dc:creator: g30rg3x
item.description:
Keywords, Component, Milestone changed

+1, but i think this should be consider in the 2.3 release

item.title: Ticket #5039 (Tags with multiple posts gives wrong pagination link) created
item.dc:creator: snakefoot
item.description:
Using the following permalink structure:

/index.php/%year%/%monthnum%/%day%/%postname%/
/index.php/articles
/index.php/tags

The link forward is correct:

/index.php/tags/pet-food/page/2/

The link backward is missing index.php:

/tags/pet-food/

P.S. When changing the tag permalink structure, then it should automatically remove any trailing slash from the tag-permalink structure (like it already does with the category structure).

/index.php/tags/

Should become:

/index.php/tags

item.title: Ticket #5037 (WordPress 2.3 doesn't finish to load when fsockopen has been disabled) updated
item.dc:creator: xknown
item.description: Mark, your patch is more consistent although I don't like the idea that versions checks take place on init hook.

item.title: Ticket #5033 (Better error_reporting and a debug mode) updated
item.dc:creator: santosj
item.description:
if (defined('WPDEBUG') && ( true == WPDEBUG) ) {
   error_reporting(E_ALL);
} else {
   error_reporting(0);
}

Oh yeah. Assume Production, unless stated otherwise in config.php.

item.title: Ticket #5034 (Impossible to have duplicate category slugs with different parents) updated
item.dc:creator: snakefoot
item.description:
Just peeked at some of the category code, and it seems there is some kind of conversion from the taxonomy + terms table to the old category format.

Sadly enough it expects a one to one relationship between the taxonomy and terms table, and gets angry when two different taxonomy entries points to the same term (Just tried to change the unique index to see what happened). It seems to use the id of the term to identify the category, where it probably should use the id from the taxonomy table.

item.title: 5037.002.diff attached to Ticket #5037
item.dc:creator: markjaquith

item.title: Ticket #5026 (Complete RTL CSSes revision for 2.2 Branch) closed
item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description:
wontfix:

Replying to mani_monaj:

There is no need to set it to 2.3 because I opened a new ticket for that (#5025) and Ryan applied the changes to 2.3 in [6146]. Just change it back to 2.2 to apply these changes to 2.2 Branch as well. (Maybe 2.2.4). [The patch is different from the one in #5025 because there is no wp-admin/css folder in 2.2]

OK great! Next time if you mention that in the ticket than it will save you and me some typing ;-)

BTW, Is 2.2.4 milestone in WP plans? If not, please close this ticket.

Doesn't sound like high enough severity to worry about it in a 2.2.x maint. release anyway.

item.title: Ticket #5037 (WordPress 2.3 doesn't finish to load when fsockopen has been disabled) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Agree that we should be preventing an infinite loop -- but not that we should limit it to wp-admin. It's really close to release, let's just fix the bug.

Checking fsockopen() is good, but line 33 also troubles me because all it tests for is "false" (which obviously is failing in the case of fsockopen() being blocked). We should be testing $fs with is_resource()

item.title: Ticket #5038 (Upgraded to 2.3 RC1, now getting database error) closed
item.dc:creator: Nazgul
item.description:
invalid:

The categories table was removed in 2.3RC1. I assume you've got a plugin running which still tries to use it.

Disable all plugins. Activate them one by one and reload your site after each one. Once you find the culprit. Contact its author and ask him to make it 2.3 compatible.

item.title: Ticket #5034 (Impossible to have duplicate category slugs with different parents) updated
item.dc:creator: snakefoot
item.description:
Would it be possible to change the term_taxonomy table so the unique key is "term_id + taxonomy + parent" ? (Instead of "term-id + taxonomy")

Then would be a matter of correcting the upgrade function, so it would create multiple entries in the term_taxonomy table if several category is has similar name but different parents.

item.title: Ticket #5038 (Upgraded to 2.3 RC1, now getting database error) created
item.dc:creator: jeanniebeannie
item.description:
The error below is showing up at the top of the screens on my site after upgrading from 2.2 to 2.3RC1 today. I tried running the upgrade script again but it wouldn't let me, saying the database is already up-to-date. Hmmm.

WordPress database error: [Table 'jeannie_wordpress.wp_categories' doesn't exist] SELECT * FROM wp_categories ORDER BY cat_name

You can see that the categories do show up (www.jeanniebeannie.com), but the error message.

Please forgive me if this has already been covered, I didn't see anything about it in the forums.

I also get the one below sometimes (like just now when I switched the theme in order to make the previous error msg visible since it was hidden by the other theme).

Warning: Cannot modify header information - headers already sent by (output started at /home/jeannie/public_html/wordpress/wp-includes/wp-db.php:160) in /home/jeannie/public_html/wordpress/wp-includes/pluggable.php on line 383

Thanks,

Jeannie

item.title: update_checks.diff attached to Ticket #5037
item.dc:creator: xknown
item.description: check if fsockopen has been disabled

item.title: Ticket #5037 (WordPress 2.3 doesn't finish to load when fsockopen has been disabled) created
item.dc:creator: xknown
item.description:
As the title states, WP enters in an infinite loop (line 35 wp-includes/update.php) when fsockopen is listed in disable_functions directive.

The attached patch contains an alternative to fix the problem, it also restrict update checks only when is_admin() is true.

item.title: Ticket #5010 (Bug in Updating attachment of a post = losing post_parent) updated
item.dc:creator: michelwp
item.description:
I agree : EXTR_SKIP introduced with 2.2 reveal that the third arg $post_parent is set by default to 0.... and the post_parent transmitted by the object cannot be created...
I don't know why both object and this arg are in the function ?
And if calling functions use this both args..
(for temporary patch I use it (3° arg) from the calling function with an internal name as $parent...)
The patch of filosofo don't keep the problem of this third arg....

item.title: Ticket #5034 (Impossible to have duplicate category slugs with different parents) updated
item.dc:creator: snakefoot
item.description: Whoops two different taxonomy can point to the same slug, so the situation with link-category and post-category is not an issue.

item.title: Ticket #5036 (Edit comments : toggle view mode) created
item.dc:creator: ozh
item.description: On edit-comments.php : it doesn't really make sense to have a link to "Mass Edit Mode" when you're already on "Mass Edit Mode", and a link to "View Mode" when you're on "View Mode". Attached is a patch to display the relevant link only.

item.title: Ticket #5034 (Impossible to have duplicate category slugs with different parents) updated
item.dc:creator: snakefoot
item.description:
Guess it is also impossible to have duplicate slugs with different taxonomy. Forexample I have a link category called "news" and I also have a post-category called "news".

But I can see that this is no longer possible with the new database design, and removing these new limitations would require a redesign of the database. And I guess this not something which is going to happen in the 2.3 branch.

Glad that WP 2.0 is kept alive for several more years :)

item.title: Ticket #5033 (Better error_reporting and a debug mode) updated
item.dc:creator: santosj
item.description:
I think it should be: 

if (defined('WPPRODUCTION') && ( true == WPPRODUCTION ) ) {
   error_reporting(0);
} else {
   error_reporting(E_ALL);
}

And have in the config.php 

WPPRODUCTION = true;

item.title: Ticket #5034 (Impossible to have duplicate category slugs with different parents) created
item.dc:creator: snakefoot
item.description:
I'm using Wordpress as a CMS tool where categories are used as macro level grouping.

Windows XP -> Utilities Windows Vista -> Utilities

This is no longer possible with WP 2.3, which ignores parent category when testing whether a slug is unique.

item.title: Ticket #5033 (Better error_reporting and a debug mode) updated
item.dc:creator: Nazgul
item.description:
Milestone changed

See #3155

item.title: const_wpdebug.diff attached to Ticket #5033
item.dc:creator: ozh
item.description: optional debug mode

item.title: Ticket #5033 (Better error_reporting and a debug mode) created
item.dc:creator: ozh
item.description:
Following a discussion on wp-hackers in September, here is a proposition for a better error_reporting handling, and an optional debug mode (plugin) developers could activate on a per-blog basis

It would consist of the following:

in wp-settings.php: 

if (defined('WPDEBUG') and WPDEBUG == true) {
   error_reporting(E_ALL);
} else {
   error_reporting(E_ALL ^ E_NOTICE);
}

Then, on wp-config.php for developers: 

define('WPDEBUG', true);

item.title: Ticket #4969 (Make wp_list_* functions all behave similarly...) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Replying to pishmishy:

That's fine if it's what you're after (and I admit for most people it is), but it'd be nice if a theme author could have option of not using a list of lists if they so desire.

I don't understand your objection, theme authors do have that option. Many themes use divs instead, for example. All the bits in there where it generates lists for sidebar items can be overriden with arguments.

item.title: Ticket #5032 (Option to disable Canonical Redirects) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Keywords, Owner, Status changed

Patch uploaded.

Ryan was +1 on this. Haven't heard from Peter or Matt.

Adds one i18n'd string:

WordPress should attempt to redirect visitors to the correct URL for their request <em>(disable this if you are having issues with infinite redirects)</em>

So we'll need to inform the polyglots list of that.

item.title: 5032.diff attached to Ticket #5032
item.dc:creator: markjaquith

item.title: Ticket #5032 (Option to disable Canonical Redirects) created
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
While I'm really excited about canonical redirects, and they're much more conservative and reliable than previous iterations, there are still going to be people who have issues. Anyone whose REQUEST_URI isn't set correctly by their PHP setup (or fixed by WordPress) is going to have issues. It's likely to be a small minority, but for the minority affected, it's a rather catastrophic failure that may cause their site to be unavailable.

As of right now, you need a plugin to disable canonical redirects. I'm loathe to introduce options, but this might be a good case for one.

I know it's late to be introducing this, but it will likely make the release go more smoothly.

item.title: Ticket #2059 (Slashes stripped in <pre> (caused by #1793)) updated
item.dc:creator: DelGurth
item.description:
Replying to mdawaffe:

Since wpautop can be called dozens of times per page loead, we should probably not use create_function().

Sounds like a wise idea. I'm new to wordpress and with the first real item I wanted to post I encountered this bug, so I was kinda in a hurry to create a fix. I was not sure if I could alter the clean_pre() function, but if I had used your method I should not have worried about it.

Thanks for using my input to kill the bug.

item.title: widgets-idea.PNG attached to Ticket #4280
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description: Widgets UI idea

item.title: Ticket #4280 (Allow to constrain widgets being displayed on certain page types only) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
How about this for a UI idea? (See attached PNG file)

It would pretty much follow the Template Hierarchy. The "Default" would be the home page. When you clicked any of the extra tabs to edit that page, you'd get an exact copy of the default if no custom setting for that type of page already exists, or the custom sidebar for that type of page if it does exist. All the pages other than the default would have a button to "remove customizations" for that sidebar page, in order to fall back to the default or archive or whatever applies.

Seems like the simplest way to do it to me.

item.title: Ticket #4686 (WXR need a version) updated
item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description:
link92, please don't comment if you aren't going to be polite, why on Earth indeed.

Versioning:

  • Helps detection of backwards compatibility issues
  • Makes handling backwards compatibility easier, more graceful
  • Allows an experience wwarning when someone trying to import from a forward version

item.title: tagcloud-class.diff attached to Ticket #5031
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description: Tag Cloud - allows classes instead of styles.

item.title: Ticket #5031 (Tag Cloud styles are hardcoded) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Keywords changed

My thought is that it's being overthought here. The tag_cloud should have a clean ability, where it does nothing more than output relative CSS classes. Like tagcloud1, tagcloud2, tagcloud37, whatever. Then the theme can define whatever styles they want for each bit in their own CSS file.

Here, I'll attach a patch to explain. It allows you to eschew the use of inline styles in favor of classes instead.

item.title: Ticket #5031 (Tag Cloud styles are hardcoded) updated
item.dc:creator: technosailor
item.description:
The code for creating gradient colors for such a routine strikes me as bloat. I tried to write some test code a variety of different ways and ended up ripping code from php.net instead. Even that is 'thick' code. My sample script for feedback:

​http://pastebin.ca/706051

And the display:

​http://technosailor.com/hextest.php

It's not WP code but could be integrated. The gradient code is more excessive than I'd prefer (and I think most devs would agree), but I toss it out there as an option. As I see it, we could just pass optional start_color and end_color vars into wp_generate_tag_cloud() with defaults of 000000 and 000000. That shouldn't spoil the status quo at all but would allow tag cloud "colors".

Thoughts?

item.title: Ticket #4686 (WXR need a version) updated
item.dc:creator: link92
item.description:
Why on earth does this require versioning? The output of the XML parser should be identical with or without a CDATA section around the commenter name…

Versioning just gives us an excuse to breaks backwards compatibility in a format that most certainly should not ever need backwards compatibility broken.

item.title: Ticket #5031 (Tag Cloud styles are hardcoded) updated
item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description: Version, Milestone changed

item.title: Ticket #5031 (Tag Cloud styles are hardcoded) created
item.dc:creator: technosailor
item.description:
We should provide a way for tag cloud styles to be set somewhere other than in the core code. Really should be the job of a theme, not the core. Yet, we are setting font-size manually. Why?

This has already come up as a problem prior to the 2.3 release. Suggest we at minimum make the styling hookable, and at most, give a css class that has relative meaning for the tag cloud.

Specifically, this would enable folks to have colored tag clouding as opposed to just font size.

item.title: Ticket #4518 (Nested <ol> <ul> lists display incorrectly with default theme) updated
item.dc:creator: Johnny_one_eye
item.description:
er whoops, better idea. instead of adding the list-style to .entry ol add this: 

	text-indent: 0px;

item.title: Ticket #4518 (Nested <ol> <ul> lists display incorrectly with default theme) updated
item.dc:creator: Johnny_one_eye
item.description:
This still does not solve the problem. I was also having it. It seems this is what's specifically causing the problem: 

.entry ul li:before, #sidebar ul ul li:before {
	content: "\00BB \0020";
	}

This can be added to fix the glitch: 

.entry ol li:before {
	content: "";
	}

However, now ol's look kind of funny. On my site I also added another line to .entry ol to make the ol's look right: 

	list-style: decimal inside;

item.title: Ticket #5029 (wp_list_categories with show_last_update=1 displays no date) created
item.dc:creator: MichaelH
item.description:
The show_last_update=1 parameter, when used with wp_list_categories, shows nothing for all categories.

$wp_version = '2.3-RC1'; $wp_db_version = 6124;

It does not work in 2.2.3 either.

item.title: Ticket #5028 (wp_dropdown_categories and wp_list_categories with show_last_update=1 ...) created
item.dc:creator: MichaelH
item.description:
The show_last_update=1 parameter, when used with wp_dropdown_categories, shows 1970-01-01 for all categories.

$wp_version = '2.3-RC1'; $wp_db_version = 6124;

It works in 2.2.3.
